questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-week history of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and fever. He has had a cough productive of foul-smelling sputum for 4 weeks. He was hospitalized for alcohol intoxication twice over the past 6 months. He has hypertension and major depressive disorder. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks 6 alcoholic beverages daily. Current medications include ramipril and fluoxetine. He appears malnourished. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 65.7 kg (145 lb); BMI is 19.1 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 147/96 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination of the chest shows dullness to percussion over the right middle lung field. An x-ray of the chest shows a lung cavity with an air-fluid level and surrounding infiltrate in the right middle lobe of the lung. Results of blood and sputum cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order bronchoscopy with drainage of the lesion
Wait for culture results before determining further management
Begin isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of vancomycin and levofloxacin may be considered in some cases of pneumonia. Vancomycin covers gram-positive bacteria, including methicillin-resistant S. aureus, while levofloxacin is a respiratory fluoroquinolone commonly used to treat pneumonia caused by gram-positive bacteria (streptococci) and atypical organisms (Mycoplasma or Chlamydia) in hospitalized patients and those with risk factors for complications such as diabetes or lung disease. This patient has a lung abscess that is most likely secondary to aspiration pneumonia, which usually has a polymicrobial etiology involving anaerobic bacteria. These agents are therefore not indicated in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy and drainage of the lesion are used in the treatment of lung abscess if the general condition or radiographic findings of the patient do not improve after 7–10 days of antibiotic treatment. Drainage of the abscess is not required as long as the abscess drains through the bronchus spontaneously, which is indicated by an air-fluid level on radiography and the presence of foul-smelling sputum.

C) INCORRECT:

Sputum cultures can help to identify the organism responsible for lung abscess. Expectorated sputum should be collected as follows: prior to initiating therapy, before eating, and after a thorough mouth rinse to reduce contamination from upper airway bacteria that do not require treatment. Waiting for the culture results, however, would be inappropriate because of the potential risk of life-threatening complications associated with lung abscess. Instead, empiric antibiotic therapy should be started immediately after collecting sputum, with therapy tailored as needed once culture results are available.

D) INCORRECT:

A combination of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol is used to treat pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) after diagnosis via sputum smear, culture, or nucleic acid amplification. TB can manifest with fever, fatigue, cough, increasing shortness of breath, and cavitation on radiography, but this patient does not have other features of TB, such as night sweats, hemoptysis, and cavitary lesions affecting the upper lobe (rather than the middle lobe). This patient's presentation is more consistent with lung abscess caused by aspiration, which requires different management.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT-guided transthoracic needle biopsy can be used to evaluate peripheral, solitary lung lesions that raise concern for pulmonary malignancy. Lung cancer can manifest with cough, shortness of breath, malnourishment, and cavitary lesions, which are commonly seen in patients with squamous cell lung cancer. Although a history of smoking is a significant risk factor for lung cancer, foul-smelling sputum is rarely seen, unless secondary anaerobic bacterial infection occurs. In addition, in patients with a suspicious solitary lesion seen on x-ray, a CT scan should be performed next to assess the risk for malignancy, and this may be followed by transbronchial or transthoracic biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. This patient may require further diagnostic workup if there is no response to treatment.

F) CORRECT:

Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics with anaerobic coverage (ampicillin/sulbactam or carbapenems) are the preferred empiric antimicrobial treatment for lung abscesses and also provide coverage against gram-positive cocci. Lung abscesses due to aspiration typically result from anaerobic bacteria, whereas lung abscesses due to hematogenous spread from IV drug use are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and streptococci. Empiric antibiotic therapy should be initiated in all patients with suspected lung abscess (e.g., those with fever, purulent sputum) and a cavitary lesion on imaging. Antibiotic therapy should be adjusted according to culture results and clinical response. In patients with beta lactam allergy, clindamycin is recommended.

CT scan of the chest can be used to confirm the diagnosis and rule out differential diagnoses of lung abscess.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lung abscess

A large thick-walled (green overlay) cavity projecting over the perihilar region of the right lung contains an air-fluid level (indicated by red line).

The differential for this appearance includes abscess (bacterial, mycobacterial, fungal), cavitary noninfectious granuloma, and cavitary malignant lesion.
questions.hint: Persistent fevers, fatigue, cough productive of foul-smelling sputum, and a lung cavity with an air-fluid level on chest x-ray indicate lung abscess. This patient's history of heavy drinking is a risk factor for aspiration.

questions.text: A previously healthy 46-year-old woman comes to the physician with a one-week history of productive cough and fatigue. Two weeks ago, she had fever, nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and myalgias that resolved with supportive care. She has not traveled out of the United States. Pulmonary examination shows dullness to percussion and increased fremitus anteriorly over the right lung. An x-ray of the chest is shown. A sputum sample is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A sputum sample is most likely to show Staphylococcus aureus, which can cause lung abscesses, especially in cases of recent or current influenza virus infection (as is likely the case in this patient). Other pathogens implicated in monomicrobial lung abscesses include Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Streptococcus anginosus. Multimicrobial infection with anaerobic bacteria that colonize the oral cavity is more common.

B) INCORRECT:

Silver-staining, gram-negative bacilli in combination with cough and fever would raise suspicion of Legionella pneumonia caused by Legionella pneumophila. Legionellosis does not commonly cause abscess formation, but rather atypical pneumonia. Expected chest x-ray findings in patients with atypical pneumonia would include diffuse, pulmonary interstitial infiltrates.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (left; PA view) and CT chest (right; lung window; top: coronal plane; bottom: sagittal plane) of a patient with Legionella pneumonia

Scattered ill-defined opacities are seen in both lungs, and extensive air space consolidation is present in the left upper lobe (green overlay). The latter is accompanied by slight elevation of the major fissure (arrowheads), indicating volume loss. Bilateral pleural effusions (red overlay), left greater than right, are present .

The imaging features of Legionella pneumonia are variable. Consolidation can manifest in a single lobe or as bilateral and multifocal opacities. Pleural effusions are common. Radiographic findings may lag behind clinical improvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a gram-intermediate, acid-fast bacteria which causes tuberculosis. This patient has no history of recent travel, contact with infected patients (incarceration, nursing homes), HIV infection, or other risk factors to suggest tuberculosis.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of gram-positive, beta-hemolytic cocci would suggest infection with group A streptococci (e.g., Streptococcus pyogenes). Although group A streptococci can cause upper respiratory infections (e.g., pharyngitis, scarlet fever) and skin infections (e.g., impetigo), pneumonia and lung abscess in a previously healthy patient would be very unusual. This patient's recent symptoms of an influenza infection make a different pathogen more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Septate, acute-branching hyphae would be indicative of infection with Aspergillus fumigatus, which can occur in preexisting lung cavities (e.g., from COPD or emphysema). It may also cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients, which classically presents with pulmonary nodules and/or an air crescent sign. Aspergillosis is not a common cause of lung abscess.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

There are diffuse reticulonodular opacities in both lungs with numerous larger nodules interspersed throughout (examples indicated by red rectangle). In the upper zone of the right lung, an ovoid lesion can be seen that is surrounded by a thin rim with normal radiolucency (arrowheads).

This finding is known as the air crescent sign and is characteristic of aspergilloma.

F) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae is an encapsulated, gram-negative coccobacillus. Although H. influenzae is a common cause of otitis media (in children) and pneumonia (in older adults), it does not commonly cause lung abscess.
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray shows a large irregularly rounded cavity with an air-fluid level projecting on the perihilar region of the right lung, indicating a lung abscess.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a seizure disorder comes to the physician because of fever, fatigue, and a productive cough with foul-smelling sputum for 2 weeks. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F). Physical examination shows dullness to percussion over the right lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows a cavitary infiltrate with an air-fluid level in the right lower lobe of the lung. Cultures of an aspirate of the infiltrate grow Peptostreptococcus and Prevotella species. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Minor skin injuries are a risk factor for purulent (e.g., folliculitis, carbuncle, skin abscess) and nonpurulent (e.g., erysipelas, cellulitis) skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs), which are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and group A Streptococcus. S. aureus can cause lung abscesses, but this patient's aspirate is positive for Peptostreptococcus and Prevotella species, anaerobic bacteria that do not colonize the skin. Furthermore, neither SSTIs nor minor skin injuries are known risk factors for lung abscesses.

B) INCORRECT:

Exposure to bat droppings during cave exploration is associated with Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus that can cause pneumonia or, in rare cases, a lung abscess. Cave exploration is not associated with the development of lung abscesses due to anaerobes such as Peptostreptococcus or Prevotella.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with tricuspid valve endocarditis are at increased risk of developing lung abscesses caused by Staphylococcus aureus, not anaerobes such as Peptostreptococcus or Prevotella.

D) INCORRECT:

A crowded housing situation can lead to the spread of many infectious diseases among inhabitants (e.g., viral illness, pneumonia, tuberculosis, skin, and soft tissue infections). While some of this patient's features (fever, fatigue, cough, and cavitary lesions) might raise concern for tuberculosis, she has not had any night sweats, weight loss, or hemoptysis. The presence of Peptostreptococcus and Prevotella species in the lung cavity suggests another disease process.

E) CORRECT:

Most lung abscesses are caused by aspiration of oropharyngeal secretions containing oral anaerobes, such as Peptostreptococcus, Prevotella, Bacteroides, and Fusobacterium. Increased growth of these bacteria can be caused by periodontal disease, dental abscesses, or tonsillitis. Altered mental status (caused by, e.g., sedation, intoxication, or seizures) and impaired swallowing further increase the risk of aspiration and thus developing lung abscesses. Other risk factors for lung abscess include bronchial obstruction (due to, e.g., lung cancer), immunocompromised state, pneumonia, bronchiectasis, and impaired respiratory mucus clearance (e.g., cystic fibrosis).

Lung abscess is less commonly caused by aerobic bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus).

F) INCORRECT:

The development of a pneumonia or lung abscess after contact with a contaminated water source (e.g., mist or vapor from an air conditioning system) is associated with Legionella, not anaerobes such as Peptostreptococcus or Prevotella.
questions.hint: Fever, fatigue, a cough productive of foul-smelling sputum, and a lung cavity with an air-fluid level on chest x-ray suggest a lung abscess.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man reports 4 weeks of fevers, weight loss, and a cough that produces purulent, foul-smelling sputum. He has a history of alcohol and substance use disorders and rarely gets medical care.
On physical examination, he has a temperature of 38.4°C, a blood pressure of 115/73 mm Hg, a heart rate of 98 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 93% while breathing ambient air. He has dullness to percussion at the left base. Laboratory studies reveal a leukocyte count of 17,200 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with 11% bands.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following empiric antimicrobial treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin and levofloxacin can be used to manage community-acquired pneumonia, but neither is adequate for an anaerobic lung abscess.

B) INCORRECT:

Although metronidazole has good anaerobic coverage, it is less useful for pulmonary abscesses because of their polymicrobial nature and predominance of gram-positive cocci.

C) CORRECT:

Anaerobic lung abscesses manifest subacutely with fevers and a cough that produces putrid sputum. Risk factors for the development of an anaerobic abscess include alcohol use disorder, seizures, and stroke, which put patients at risk for aspiration. Ampicillin-sulbactam (or, alternatively, clindamycin) is currently recommended for treating anaerobic lung abscesses.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for an anaerobic lung abscess is ampicillin-sulbactam, as it offers good anaerobic and polymicrobial coverage.

D) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin would be appropriate for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection, which can cause cavitary pneumonia. However, methicillin-resistant S. aureus pneumonia manifests acutely, making this diagnosis unlikely and vancomycin an incorrect choice.

E) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin and levofloxacin can be used to manage community-acquired pneumonia, but neither is adequate for an anaerobic lung abscess.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 10-day history of fever, chills, and cough productive of thick, foul-smelling sputum. He has a 15-year history of epilepsy that has been difficult to control and reports occasional nocturnal episodes where he wakes up disoriented on the floor. Physical examination reveals reduced breath sounds and localized crackles in the right posterior lung region (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
14 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


Chest X-ray: Cavitary opacity in the right lower lobe
Which of the following antibiotic regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin targets certain gram-positive pathogens but lacks anaerobic coverage. The patient's history and presentation suggest an anaerobic infection due to aspiration, which amoxicillin cannot adequately treat. The severity of the infection, indicated by elevated white blood cell count and cavitary lesion, requires more aggressive treatment with anaerobic coverage.

B) CORRECT:

Aspiration of oropharyngeal contents, particularly in individuals with altered consciousness such as those with epilepsy, can lead to anaerobic bacterial infection in the lungs. This results in tissue necrosis and cavitary lung abscesses, as seen on imaging. The foul-smelling sputum is indicative of anaerobic infection. Intravenous clindamycin is effective against anaerobes commonly found in the oral cavity and penetrates lung tissue well, making it suitable for treating aspiration-induced lung abscesses.

Key learning point: In patients with risk factors for aspiration, such as poorly controlled epilepsy, lung abscesses are often caused by aspiration of oropharyngeal contents, leading to polymicrobial infections with aerobic and anaerobic organisms.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin is used for community-acquired pneumonia, covering typical and some atypical bacteria. However, the patient's presentation suggests an anaerobic infection due to aspiration, which this regimen does not adequately cover. The presence of a cavitary lesion and foul-smelling sputum indicates the need for anaerobic coverage.

D) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is effective against gram-positive organisms, including MRSA, but does not cover anaerobes. The patient's symptoms and history suggest an aspiration-induced lung abscess, typically caused by anaerobic bacteria. Vancomycin would not target the likely causative organisms in this scenario.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder comes to your clinic with 2 weeks of fever, fatigue, and a productive cough with foul-smelling sputum. Her temperature is 38.3°C. On examination, there is dullness to percussion over the right lung fields. A chest x-ray shows a cavitary infiltrate with an air-fluid level in the right lower lobe. Cultures from an aspirate of the infiltrate grow Peptostreptococcus and Prevotella species. Which one of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for her condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Most lung abscesses are caused by aspiration of oropharyngeal secretions containing oral anaerobes, such as Peptostreptococcus, Prevotella, Bacteroides, and Fusobacterium. Increased growth of these bacteria can be caused by periodontal disease, dental abscesses, or tonsillitis. Altered mental status (caused by, e.g., sedation, intoxication, or seizures) and impaired swallowing further increase the risk of aspiration and thus developing lung abscesses. Other risk factors for lung abscess include bronchial obstruction (due to, e.g., lung cancer), immunocompromised state, pneumonia, bronchiectasis, and impaired respiratory mucus clearance (e.g., cystic fibrosis).

Lung abscess is less commonly caused by aerobic bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus).

Key learning point: Lung abscesses are most often caused by aspiration of oral anaerobes, especially in individuals with periodontal disease or impaired consciousness.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with tricuspid valve endocarditis are at increased risk of developing lung abscesses caused by Staphylococcus aureus, not anaerobes such as Peptostreptococcus or Prevotella.

C) INCORRECT:

A crowded housing situation can lead to the spread of many infectious diseases among inhabitants (e.g., viral illness, pneumonia, tuberculosis, skin, and soft tissue infections). While some of this patient's features (fever, fatigue, cough, and cavitary lesions) might raise concern for tuberculosis, she has not had any night sweats, weight loss, or hemoptysis. The presence of Peptostreptococcus and Prevotella species in the lung cavity suggests another disease process.

D) INCORRECT:

Exposure to bat droppings during cave exploration is associated with Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus that can cause pneumonia or, in rare cases, a lung abscess. Cave exploration is not associated with the development of lung abscesses due to anaerobes such as Peptostreptococcus or Prevotella.

E) INCORRECT:

The development of a pneumonia or lung abscess after contact with a contaminated water source (e.g., mist or vapor from an air conditioning system) is associated with Legionella, not anaerobes such as Peptostreptococcus or Prevotella.
questions.hint: Fever, fatigue, a cough productive of foul-smelling sputum, and a lung cavity with an air-fluid level on chest x-ray suggest a lung abscess.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with alcohol use disorder presents with a 3-week history of fever, a productive, foul-smelling cough, and weight loss. Physical examination shows dullness to percussion in the left lower lobe. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial antibiotic therapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The chest x-ray shows a large cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level in the left lower lobe, suggestive of a lung abscess. Ceftriaxone alone lacks anaerobic coverage, which is essential for treating lung abscesses in patients with aspiration risk factors like alcohol use disorder. While ceftriaxone would be appropriate for typical community-acquired pneumonia, lung abscesses due to aspiration are typically caused by anaerobic bacteria. Ceftriaxone could be used in combination with metronidazole for anaerobic coverage, but monotherapy is inadequate for this diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The chest x-ray shows a large cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level in the left lower lobe, suggestive of a lung abscess. Ampicillin-sulbactam provides broad-spectrum coverage, including anaerobic bacteria, which are the most common cause of lung abscesses in patients with aspiration risk factors such as alcohol use disorder. The combination covers both aerobic and anaerobic organisms typically found in aspiration-related lung abscesses and is a first-line empiric antibiotic choice for this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

The chest x-ray shows a large cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level in the left lower lobe, suggestive of a lung abscess. Vancomycin is reserved for suspected methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections and does not provide the necessary anaerobic coverage for typical aspiration-related lung abscesses. There are no risk factors for MRSA in this patient. While vancomycin would be appropriate for lung abscesses caused by hematogenous spread from IV drug use (which typically involve Staphylococcus aureus), this patient's presentation is more consistent with aspiration-related abscess.

D) INCORRECT:

The chest x-ray shows a large cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level in the left lower lobe, suggestive of a lung abscess. Doxycycline lacks adequate anaerobic coverage, which is essential for treating lung abscesses in patients with aspiration risk factors like alcohol use disorder. While doxycycline is effective against atypical respiratory pathogens such as Mycoplasma, Chlamydia, and Rickettsia, and has some activity against community-acquired MRSA, it does not provide the necessary coverage against oral anaerobic bacteria that are the predominant pathogens in aspiration-related lung abscesses.

E) INCORRECT:

The chest x-ray shows a large cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level in the left lower lobe, suggestive of a lung abscess. Ciprofloxacin lacks adequate anaerobic coverage and is not recommended for lung abscesses. As a second-generation fluoroquinolone, ciprofloxacin is effective against gram-negative bacteria (including Pseudomonas aeruginosa) but does not have the enhanced anaerobic activity of newer respiratory fluoroquinolones like levofloxacin and moxifloxacin.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with diabetes mellitus presents with 2 weeks of fever and productive cough. He has been taking amoxicillin prescribed by urgent care for the past 5 days without improvement. Vital signs are BP, 140/85 mm Hg; P, 98; T, 101.2°F (38.4°C); oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Chest examination shows dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds in the right middle lobe. The rest of the examination and review of systems are unremarkable. Chest CT is shown. Blood and sputum cultures are obtained. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Switch to oral clindamycin and arrange outpatient pulmonology follow-up
Start IV ampicillin-sulbactam and admit to hospital
Start IV vancomycin and consult infectious diseases
Start IV ceftriaxone and schedule bronchoalveolar lavage within 24 hours
Switch to empiric antifungal therapy and obtain HIV testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The CT shows thick-walled cavitary lesions with air-fluid levels consistent with lung abscess. This patient appears systemically ill with treatment failure on oral antibiotics and hypoxemia. Oral antibiotics are insufficient for seriously ill patients with lung abscess, who require parenteral therapy and admission for monitoring, supportive care, and abscess drainage if indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – The CT shows thick-walled cavitary lesions with air-fluid levels consistent with lung abscess. This patient requires admission given systemic illness, treatment failure, and hypoxemia. Empiric therapy must include anaerobic coverage since anaerobic bacteria are the most common causative pathogens in lung abscess. Ampicillin-sulbactam provides appropriate broad-spectrum coverage, including anaerobes. Drainage would be indicated for large abscesses over 6-8 cm, significant hemoptysis, or inadequate response despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, e.g., persistent fever or inadequate radiologic improvement.

C) INCORRECT:

The CT shows thick-walled cavitary lesions with air-fluid levels consistent with lung abscess. Vancomycin lacks anaerobic coverage, which is essential for empiric therapy in lung abscess. While infectious disease consultation may be helpful, pulmonology or interventional radiology consultation would be more appropriate to assess the need for drainage procedures if the patient fails to respond to appropriate antibiotic therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

The CT shows thick-walled cavitary lesions with air-fluid levels consistent with lung abscess. Ceftriaxone monotherapy lacks anaerobic coverage, which is essential for empiric therapy in lung abscess. Bronchoalveolar lavage is a diagnostic procedure used to obtain samples from the lower respiratory tract and would not provide therapeutic benefit for treating lung abscesses. However, bronchoscopic drainage might be considered if the abscess meets drainage criteria.

E) INCORRECT:

The CT shows thick-walled cavitary lesions with air-fluid levels consistent with lung abscess. Bacterial infection is the most common cause of lung abscess, and empiric antibiotic therapy with anaerobic coverage should be initiated immediately, alongside identifying indications for drainage. Diabetes mellitus is a risk factor for bacterial lung abscess, so the presence of lung abscess in a diabetic patient does not in itself justify investigating for other causes of immunocompromise in the absence of HIV risk factors. Switching to antifungal therapy in this patient rather than starting appropriate bacterial therapy would delay necessary treatment and could worsen outcomes. HIV testing and antifungal therapy could be considered if there was an inadequate response to treatment or an atypical pathogen was identified via cultures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of fever, productive cough, and weight loss. Chest CT reveals a cavitary lesion in the right lower lobe with an air-fluid level. Which of the following features would be an indication for interventional drainage?

choices.text: Cavitary lesion with thick, irregular walls
Location in the posterior segment of the upper lobe

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

 Correct – The lesion described is consistent with a lung abscess. Abscesses > 6–8 cm in size frequently do not respond to antibiotic therapy alone and are an indication for interventional drainage. Other indications for drainage include significant hemoptysis and inadequate response despite appropriate antibiotic therapy with persistent fever and purulent sputum. A 9-cm abscess would require either bronchoscopic drainage or percutaneous drainage in addition to antibiotic therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

The lesion described is consistent with a lung abscess. Fever on presentation is a common clinical feature of lung abscess, but it is not itself an indication for drainage. The decision for interventional management is based on abscess size, hemoptysis, or treatment failure rather than initial temperature.

C) INCORRECT:

Cavitary lesions with thick, irregular walls are typical radiographic findings of lung abscesses that help establish the diagnosis, but cavity wall appearance does not determine the need for drainage.

D) INCORRECT:

An air-fluid level is a common radiographic finding in lung abscesses that helps confirm the diagnosis, but it is not itself an indication for drainage. The presence of an air-fluid level does not determine the need for interventional management.

E) INCORRECT:

The lesion described is consistent with a lung abscess. The anatomical location of the abscess does not determine the need for drainage. Abscesses in any location can be managed conservatively with antibiotics if they are small and responding to treatment, or require drainage based on size and treatment response.
